fields.description:
It is a critical need for our systems to have EC2 instances to startup, not with a randomly created Volume out of the provided snapshot ID, but instead with a specific volume which ID is known from us.

The scenario is the following.
When we start a cloud instance and perform a builds on it, since instances memory is not persistent, we save all our changes to the attached EBS Volume. As you know the Volume is generated out of a provided snapshot ID but luckily not deleted from the AWS Management console of the Amazon user profile. That mean, changes are kept in the Volumes until they are manually deleted via the AWS Management console.

Here comes the issue that, very often we would like to start an instance later with exactly the status of few days before that is actually the current content of a volume A previously created at that time.

The only way out for us right now, is to start a new instance based on the same configuration that the one of few days ago that we want to replicate. Based on the snapshot ID a new EBS volume is created but absolutely useless for us since we want to be able to get the status of the old attached volume, therefore preceed by:

    * login the AWS Management console
    * locate the running instance & the volume attached to that instance
    * detach the newly created volume
    * attach the old volume (which ID remained available in the AWS Management console)
    * login via SSH in the cloud instance
    * mount the attached old volume back to the /mnt/bamboo-ebs
    * start the necessary tools on the instance manually

As you can see this is a great performance issue for us that can be easily solved if there were an option to bind a specific Volume ID in a give instance configuration. This way when starting that instance, that volume only available for that specific user account could be in an automated way attached to the instance and ready to use.

The feature request (to be able to specify a volume that should be mounted to an elastic instance) would go along with the requirement that this volume should be not be deleted when the  elastic instance is going to shutdown.
fields.summary: Option to specify ebs volume instead of snapshot - keep volume alive after elastic instance shutdown

fields.description:
At least both "Recently build" streams feed and dashboard suffer from this problem. 

When you first load the dashboard all umlaut names are fine, say "Emmi Mämmi" is displayed correctly. But when you wait for background update then when it happens the name changes to "Emmi M�mmi" (on my firefox the 'ä', umlaut-a is displayed as question mark). If you hover over the name the full name is shown correctly in the popup.

Recently build feed does not work at all if the users have umlauts in their names. FireFox's error console gives invalid XML errors from response (even though it should be UTF-8).
fields.summary: AJAX requests do not handle umlaut characters in user's name correctly

fields.description:
Bamboo plans that use virtual clouds with dynamic creation of agents may suffer from the loss of build information & artefacts due to the Bamboo remote agent 'going offline' during the build.

This can make the attempt to diagnose any failures problematic; as all information generated during the build is no longer available to the Bamboo user that is interested in that plan.

It would be beneficial to retain the build information and make it available, rather than disposing of it.
fields.summary: Retain build information when the Bamboo remote agent 'goes offline' during the build

fields.description:
Bamboo automatically integrates Clover with Ant, Maven and Grails even when the build is configured with manual Clover integration:
{code}
Starting to build 'TEST - Default'
... running command line: /Applications/dev/apache-ant-1.7.1/bin/ant clover.fullclean -Djava.io.tmpdir=/var/folders/i5/i5k0y8P7GOagFji106y-0++++TM/-Tmp-/TEST-DEF -f build.xml build -Dclover.skip.json=true -Dclover.skip.report=true -Dclover.optimization.enabled=false -lib /Users/asridhar/.m2/repository/com/cenqua/clover/clover/3.0.1/clover-3.0.1.jar -listener com.atlassian.clover.ci.AntIntegrationListener -Dclover.license.path=/Users/asridhar/Bamboo/code/atlassian-bamboo-2.6/bamboo-homes/8085/xml-data/build-dir/131073/TEST-DEF/.clover/clover.license
... in : /Users/asridhar/Bamboo/code/atlassian-bamboo-2.6/bamboo-homes/8085/xml-data/build-dir/131073/TEST-DEF
... using java.home: /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Versions/1.6.0/Home
{code}

h3. Workaround

There is a patched Clover plugin JAR (with the fix) attached to this ticket. To apply the patch:
# Shutdown Bamboo 2.6
# Remove <Bamboo>/webapp/WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-bamboo-plugin-clover-2.6.jar
# Download the [atlassian-bamboo-plugin-clover-2.6_BAM-5920.jar|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/38894/atlassian-bamboo-plugin-clover-2.6_BAM-5920.jar] file to <Bamboo>/webapp/WEB-INF/lib/ directory.
# Restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: Automatic Clover Integration is Performed for Grails, Maven and Ant, When Manual Integration is Configured

fields.description:
Changes to enable concurrent builds means that the builds directory exists for each agent.
This isn't required if the concurrent builds are turned off, so we should use the base directory.

h3. Workaround
You can revert Bamboo and use the old build-dir directory structure, by applying the patch attached to this ticket. To apply the patch:
# Shutdown Bamboo,
# Create the following directory heirarchy:
{code}<Bamboo-Install>/webapp/WEB-INF/classes/com/atlassian/bamboo/build/fileserver
{code}
# Download the {{DefaultBuildDirectoryManager_BAM-5918.class}} file attached to this ticket, and copy it to the folder from step (2).
# Restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: Add workaround for when concurrent builds are disabled to use single working directory

fields.description:

running command line: cmd.exe /c call C:\ant\apache-ant-1.7.1\bin\ant.bat '-Djava.io.tmpdir="C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Local Settings\Temp\TRUNK-MAIN"' -f bamboo/build.xml compile

If you specify a "bamboo.build.parent.java.io.tmpdir" that doesn't have spaces, that should work as a workaround.

fields.description:
Our Software is split up into 5 depending suprojects (different svn's and buildscripts)
Furthermore we use Bamboo for this C++ compilation on multiple Platforms (x32/x64) * (Windows, Mac, Linux (Ubuntu, Suse...))

So the Problem is the binary dependency:
* Each project depends of the libraries, created by the foregoing project
* We need a way to trigger a build plan/project on multiple machines parallel
** My workaround whould be, creating multiple Plans and Projects for each subProject and Platform. But this leads to n*m projects with just a different in the capabilety matching each plan only for one target machine

It would be cool if
* There would be an environment Variable pointing to the build-directory of the Parent Plan
* There would be a strategie for building the same project on multi platforms in parralel
fields.summary: Depending Projects on Multiple Platforms

fields.description:
see screenshot and compare it with the log entries bellow:
{noformat}
2010-06-01 10:55:05,608 DEBUG [QuartzScheduler_Worker-8] [LocalAgentManagerImpl] Trying to match requirements... com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.capability.RequirementSetImpl@5c8c9c5d[[system.jdk.JDK LIKE .*, system.builder.mvn2.Maven 2.1 LIKE .*]]
2010-06-01 10:55:05,609 DEBUG [QuartzScheduler_Worker-8] [LocalAgentManagerImpl] Added agent panda.sydney.atlassian.com(id = 84017158)
{noformat}

LocalAgentManagerImpl.getExecutableAgents should not return offline agents. Currently it returns them and it leads to a bug in "Automatic elastic instance management" code. This happens because when we check if any enabled agents can run a build we find that there is one and don't start a new one.

The problem might also cause issues in other places.
fields.summary: Elastic instances don't get started because LocalAgentManagerImpl.getExecutableAgents returns offline agents

fields.description:
The wording PARENT-PLAN triggered by child CHILD-PLAN may confuse.
The real trigger reason for PARENT-PLAN are the 'unbuilt' changes. It is of secondary interest that PARENT-PLAN was triggered by the blocking strategy of CHILD-PLAN. If there were no changes for PARENT-PLAN it would not need to be built.

The wording for the build reason on PARENT-PLAN should be the normal 'changes by ...'
fields.summary: Confusing wording for trigger reason when parent build triggered by child with blocking strategy.

fields.description:
I am developing a plugin under the "Starter" license to see if we can easily get Bamboo to fit into our workflow before purchasing a more appropriate license.

I am trying to implement a dynamic number of per-build-plan configurable options via a preBuildAction, and was hoping to use a numeric counter in the variable name to both keep them unique, and make them easily detectable.

However, when I use this numeric counter I receive an "org.w3c.dom.DOMException: INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR: An invalid or illegal XML character is specified." error when I submit an edit from the "Builder" configuration section.

This causes the exception on edit submit: [@ww.textfield name='custom.variables.1.name' /]
This work OK: [@ww.textfield name='custom.variables.one.name' /]

Is this working as intended? Or should I be able to use numeric characters? I do not follow how a number could be an invalid XML character, especially since I could put numbers into the "custom.variables.one.name" textfield without incident.

Thank you.
fields.summary: INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR when a configurable plugin has numbers in a field name

fields.description:
An entry in commit_files is created for each committed file _times_ the number of plans triggered by this check in.
Example: commit 2 files, 10 plans are affected and built results in 20 rows in commit_files with identical information (except the commit_id)

In a particular case https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-2985 a svn propedit was applied to all files in a repository (app 230.000) with app 300 plans affected. This created app 7 MILLION rows in COMMIT_FILES.

Bamboo becomes unusable and runs out of heap space frequently.
fields.summary: reduce redundancy in tables commit_files

fields.description:
Bamboo should be able to do partial checkout, instead of checking out the entire repository.

Bamboo does have an include/exclude feature for monitoring changes but it would be nice to ignore directories during checkout

From BAM-3665:
Many projects using Subversion avoid svn:externals and instead use sparse directories that came with svn 1.5
{noformat}
svn co --depth=files http://svn.example.com/software/trunk
svn update trunk/my_project trunk/shared
{noformat}
fields.summary: Ability to exclude files from checkout, sparse checkouts

{code}

h5. Cause
In the Turkish alphabet there are two letters for 'i', dotless and dotted. The problem is that the dotless 'i' in lowercase becomes the dotless in uppercase. At first glance this wouldn't appear to be a problem; however, the problem lies in what programmers do with upper and lowercases in their code.

h5. Workaround

Set the java locale to
{code}
-Duser.country=EN
-Duser.language=en
{code}
Please see [this doc|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Bamboo+on+start-up], to find out how to change the locale.

fields.description:
The subversion installed on the default elastic bamboo AMI uses its own bundled ssl library.  This library doesn't know where to look for the root CA certificates (/etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt), and so consequently no matter what URL you hit, if it's https, the SVN client will throw an error saying that it doesn't trust it.

I'm not sure where the build of SVN came from that is installed on the agents, if we compiled it ourselves then the solution is to point SVN at the fedoras OpenSSL installation.  If not, then we need to compile our own, as it's pretty stupid having an SVN install that doesn't support SSL.
fields.summary: Subversion on default AMI doesn't trust any root CAs

fields.description:
To enable a mod_jk connection to a proxy or load balancer, jetty needs to load the mod-ajp connector.

jetty-ajp-<jetty-verison>.jar should be part of the bamboo standalone distribution.

The connector can be configured in jetty.xml as 

<Call name="addConnector">
  <Arg>
    <New class="org.mortbay.jetty.ajp.Ajp13SocketConnector">
      <Set name="port">8009</Set>
    </New>
  </Arg>
</Call>
fields.summary: Include jetty-ajp-x.x.x.jar into standalone distribution to enable AJP connector

fields.description:
If I have three builds:
- Build A (scans repository for changes)
- Build B (dependant/child plan on Build A)
- Build C (dependant/child plan on Build C)

I commit to the repository for Build A. That triggers:
- Build A-5
- Build B-6
- Build C-99

Then when there is a commit to the source code repository for Build A triggering A-5, I don't see that when looking at the page for B-6 or C-99. Ultimately, I'd like to be able to wrap up all source code commits on upstream builds, showing me when looking at the failed C-99 that it was changes that triggered A-5 that caused the build, rather than having to walk up the chain of upstream builds to determine that manually.
fields.summary: Pass source code commits to dependent plans to see ultimate reason for build

fields.description:
One of our DBA's emailed me, said we really should fix these missing indexes. I said Bamboo is a 3rd party black-box app and we shouldn't add indexes in the event that we screw up a future upgrade because your upgrade script doesn't account for someone already manually adding the indexes. So here is his email. 

From: Jason Strate 
Sent: Tuesday, May 18, 2010 10:59 AM
To: Kelly Schoenhofen
Subject: Missing Indexes on Bamboo

CREATE NONCLUSTERED INDEX IX_USERCOMMIT_BUILDRESULTSUMMARYID ON [USER_COMMIT]([BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_ID])

CREATE NONCLUSTERED INDEX IX_BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_BUILDNUMBER ON [BUILDRESULTSUMMARY]([BUILD_NUMBER])

fields.description:
There seems to be a confusion on which of the interfaces (PlanAware, BuildAware) should be used in which actions. 
Actions: ConfigureBuildBuilder, ConfigureBuildPostAction, ConfigureBuildRepository implement only PlanAware however these are used in build wizard and I'd expect that these would implement rather BuildAware.

The task is:
- to explain which interface should be used for regular plans and which in the Chains functionality
- validate existing implementations of PlanAware and BuildAware interfaces
fields.summary: Validate usage of PlanAware vs BuildAware interfaces

fields.description:
Currently only 'Access', 'Create', 'Restricted Admin' and 'Admin' permissions can be globally set.

In hosted Bamboo, such as JIRA Studio, users do not have 'Admin' permissions and therefore cannot edit a plan or manually start a build if the plan was not created by the user himself/herself.

Customers can bulk edit plan permissions to add 'Edit', 'Build' and 'Clone' permissions to users/groups. However, this does not apply to future new projects.

The process is rather painful for hosted customers.
fields.summary: Add 'Edit', 'Build' and 'Clone' permissions to Global Permissions

fields.description:
Instead of producing a simple one-line message when a user attempts to authenticate with invalid credentials, Bamboo dumps a 108-line stack-trace every time.
While this doesn't actually cause any direct issues, it fills the logs with noise and makes it harder to find information about genuine problems within the application.
fields.summary: Log an exception on authentication failure instead of dumping a stack-trace to the logfile

fields.description:
[Some Background|https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Deadlock+issues+in+Bamboo+2.6]
This issue is for deadlocks in a specific code path - BuildNumber generation.

Problems:
1. We unnecessary create 2 transactions one when DefaultPlanManager.generateBuildNumber is called and then another one within the first transaction when PlanHibernateDao.generateBuildNumberNewTx. In situation when many threads enter the first transaction and wait for the connection for the second(inner) transaction we get a deadlock.
2. To ensure the uniqueness of build number we need to use synchronization inside java code. However right now we synchronize from within transaction which is wrong. It can lead to the situation when one thread changed value and exited the synchronized block however has not yet committed the value. Another thread that entered the synchronized block will see a stale value.
fields.summary: Deadlock during BuildNumber generation

fields.description:
The options in the build strategy dropdown in a plan's source repository tab are as follows (on my instance)

* Polling the repository for changes
* Repository triggers the build when changes are committed
* Cron based scheduling
* Single Daily Build
* Manual & dependent builds only

I've always interpreted this to mean that dependency builds only occur when you set a build strategy of "Manual & dependent builds only".  But it turns out I'm wrong, and at least when Single Daily Build is chosen, builds will actually still occur in response to a parent build.  Is that the intended behaviour?

Why does the last option say "& dependent builds" if it always applies?  Why doesn't the previous option say "Single daily build & dependent builds"?
fields.summary: Build strategy of "Single Daily Build" still allows dependent builds although it doesn't say it does.

fields.description:
Bamboo now requires that the system property {{bamboo.paths.set.allowed}} be set with the value of {{true}} to allow a Bamboo administrator to change the following directory paths via the Bamboo Admin user interface:

* Import directory
* Export directory
* Backup directory

If this property is not set, then the Bamboo UI will only permit the modification of file names for the above (and not their paths).

fields.description:
I was investigating [this question|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257340452] on the forums.  I'm not positive, but I think this user has uncovered a bug...  It looks like {{ModuleDescriptor.init()}} is called before external plugins are loaded, so calling {{plugin.loadClass()}} within {{init()}} will throw an {{IllegalPluginStateException}}.  (I guess that bundled plugins are treated differently?)  Fortunately the exception text has a helpful suggestion:

bq. Move all classloading into the {{enabled()}} method, and be sure to properly drop class and instance references in {{disabled()}}.

I think this blocks developers from writing report collector plugins.
fields.summary: ReportCollectorModuleDescriptor.init() tries to load plugin classes

fields.description:
I have a repository with a post-commit hook to trigger a release build on Bamboo 2.5.1.  The release build is set to a Trigger Build Strategy, and uses a Maven2 builder to run the following:

mvn -B release:prepare release:perform

This will cause Bamboo to checkout from the repository, build, tag the release, and then commit the next development snapshot to the repository.  Once the build has finished, Bamboo starts in on another build, and will continue in this "build, commit, build, commit" loop until manually canceled.

I thought at first this was the post-commit hook's fault, so I removed it, but left the build strategy as Trigger Build Strategy.  I then manually triggered the release build from within Bamboo.  Same result... an infinite build loop.

Taking a look at the code, it seems like DetectChangesAfterBuildCompletedListener is the culprit, because it explicitly fires a ChangeDetectionRequiredEvent if the build strategy is TriggeredBuildStrategy.  There's probably a good reason for this, but for me, it's a blocker on integrating Bamboo any further into our build process.

I verified this to be the case for both Git and Subversion repositories.
fields.summary: Bamboo + TriggeredBuildStrategy + maven-release-plugin = infinite build loop

fields.description:
Here's my use case: I'm opening a SSH connection to my machine at work and I tunnel localhost:8085 to remote kozlak:8085. I access Bamboo using http://localhost:8085/bamboo. In Bamboo I open the dashboard and I can see activity stream without icons and links are unusable. Sample entry from activity stream looks like: {code}
  • Bamboo - Trunk Functional Tests build BAM-TRUNKFT-23 failed
    Updated by mchai, Build took 41 minutes.
    • {code} The "http://kozlak:8085/bamboo" URL is the Base URL configured in Bamboo but I think that here URL coming from the actual request shall be used - in this case "http://localhost:8085/bamboo"
fields.summary: Activity stream links and icons are unusable when Bamboo accessed via SSH tunnel

this happens regardless of an existing clover related artifact setting.

The artifact target directory should be based on the clover result file settings in the builder config.

The clover result file settings in the builder config are not taken into consideration, the Clover Report (System) is inserted regardless.

fields.description:
C:\svnrepo\hooks>C:\Bamboo-2.5.5-std\scripts\svn-triggers\postCommitBuildTrigger.py http://localhost:8085 STACK-LOCAL
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Bamboo-2.5.5-std\scripts\svn-triggers\postCommitBuildTrigger.py", line 12, in <module>
    fileHandle = urllib2.urlopen(remoteCall)
NameError: name 'urllib2' is not defined


For python 3.0 it should be
{code}
#!/usr/bin/python
#
# ./postCommitBuildTrigger.py http://bamoo.atlassian.com/bamboo/ myBuildName

import sys
import urllib.request;

baseUrl = sys.argv[1]
buildKey = sys.argv[2]

remoteCall = baseUrl + "/api/rest/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=" + buildKey
fileHandle = urllib.request.urlopen(remoteCall)
fileHandle.close()
{code}
fields.summary: python trigger scripts are not python 3.0 compatible.
